reviewText:
In personal opinion, MX vs. ATV is the best motocross/offroad series, after ATV Offroad Fury. Since that title is not available on PC, I made due with purchasing this game as a substitute, and gladly upheld it. The game is no more than more than a couple of career races, as well as features a solo/multiplayer free roam mode as well, perfect for if you and a couple of friends would like to show off tricks to each other, or battle it out head to head in a national series race.

The game has several vehicles to choose from, not only MX/ATV, but also dune buggies and sports trucks. Customization is a little lacking but is quite noticable as you progress through the career and upgrade your parts. Same can be said with visual customization, as there are only a few paint styles to choose from, mostly game brand (maybe they're real? I never took the time to check into it) paints for your vehicle, coming in only 4 or 5 different colors (red, orange, yellow, blue, black).

Head to head can be sometimes challenging, even on easy mode the last levels seemed to be proven more skillful. I easily could beat pro mode games though, it was not too much of a challenge, since this game is aimed at a wider age group audience, the game does have challenging and non challenging areas.

All in all, the game is perfectly great for anyone who is a racing/offroad fan and would like a good game to relax and play.

reviewText:
I'm conflicted to whether I really like it, or simply like it. Trust me, there's a big difference. Either way, the game is definitely worth a look for hardcore racing fans to casual gamers looking to try something new.

MX vs. ATV Reflex is an off road racing and stunt game made for enthusiasts. It's also perfectly welcoming to casual gamers with it's well rounded sensitivity (and accuracy) towards in-game accidents. I like the game, but little elements make me dislike it for not being better. The game itself is overall well put together and complimented by a welcoming and to the point visual tutorial.

Overall, the gameplay is pretty respectable.The absolute first thing that bugged me was the first person view. I couldn't see the bike or handlebars until I was in motion or if the bike was bumping upwards. Going from MotoGP 13 first person to this is just absolutely horrible. It feels decently adequate but the feel of having absolute full control isn't here. To be in full control, one needs to play in third person view to completely enjoy the game and character stunt movements. My only other complaint is the steering. MotoGP isn't perfect in it's steering, but it feels quite realistic when doing so. Here, it feels choppy or sort of skippy. It doesn't interfere so much in the game play but for people looking for exact motor bike steering, it isn't exactly here. It feels like the game is caught between being an arcade game and a simulation game, such as it's unable to decide which one to be. I find that most successful racing games actually find a balance between the two, REFLEX may have just found it. They sort of force you to stay on course (and will make you respawn if you don't) but there's always a few options here and there to take your own sort of short cut off the track.

Additionally, the game is quite gripping and provides for some serious fun. The different game modes include free-roam, race, and stunt. What makes this game quite unique though is that the right analog stick looks after the body movements while the left deals with the bike. This is a fantastic addition to the game as turns can be done on a dime if done right. This also helps rotate the bike in the air while doing stunts. Jumps are pretty rewarding and landings are decently accurate and feel right when their put together back to back. There is a system that exists within the game where if your character loses his balance, you have to use the right thumb stick and push it in a direction multiple times to avoid falling off the bike. Another system to be appreciated as it keeps you on your toes.The driving scheme in general is very beautiful once you get ahold of it.

Graphics are absolutely fantastic as tire, bike and body marks on the ground are amazingly drawn. The terrain deformation is astounding. What bugs me the most is the first person view. I wouldn't mind seeing more of the handle bars. Then again, I may have been spoiled by playing MOTOGP first. In addition to the bikes (and unfortunately), players cannot see inside of the buggie or the pick-up truck when in first person as well. I would recommend running the settings first before launching the actual game. Going from 30 to 60fps left me speachless. In addition to good looks, the replays offer a highlight reel which is pretty solid. Watch some solid jumps be pulled off or accidents. The tracks are also well designed and differ from one another (from stadiums to snow-y mountains). Riders sometimes will move their head and check their peripherals while riding. Sounds are pretty decent. The engines vary between bikes and the crowd will make a ohhh" sound if you wipe out.

For future MX vs ATV games

reviewText: Reflex is what happens when you take extreme MX + ATV racing, remove all the risk of death and crippling injury but keep all of the thrill. Its legitimately the most fun you will have in a game of this sort. Now, it may not look visually stunning, but the gameplay is simply unrivaled. The main mechanic that sets Reflex apart from just about everything else is how you can shift the rider's weight around, this allows a huge degree of control so you can pull off longer, farther jumps and more extreme landings. You can also perform tricks at anytime(when you're in stadiums the crowds go wild when you do) which adds an interesting degree of freedom and you feel like a badass. You get to play through a huge variety of races across many different locations, you also get to costumize your rider and tune your rides. Basically there is a lot to do in this game and its all well executed. A solid 9/10 from me, it loses 1 point cuz it doesn't look outrageously awesome due to occasional pop-ins, but gameplay wise its great!

reviewText:
MX vs ATV Reflex  is one of a motocross / off-road racing series collaborated by 3 game developers such as  â€œDouble Helix Games, Rainbow Studios and Nordic Gamesâ€. It was first published by Nordic Games in 2010. However, only Rainbow Studios and Nordic Games have continued with the series publishing two more games in late 2015.

The game has a single-player campaign and a multiplayer which, somewhat surprisingly, still continues to be somewhat active. The game gives you a variety of vehicles including motorcycles, ATVs, UTVs, sport trucks and buggies. In order to get them you must unlock them in the single-player mode. The campaign is chapterized into a small series of races and challenges rewarding you with a different unlockable customization either for your vehicle or for your driver. You  can customize almost everything starting with the parts of the vehicles through to the visual customizations for vehicle and driver. Thankfully these do not take too much currency as you just need to beat a race or challenge.

In regards to the graphics Iâ€™d like to point out first that the settings are only accessible outside of the game and you can only choose from a number of pre-set options. Overall, the game has solid graphics including cool mud and water effects/physics but they are dated compared to newer titles. The presentation is accompanied with some cool, mostly metallic, soundtracks and a voice over who does a notable job.

The game has a good tutorial. It provides both keyboard and gamepad instructions and provides some tips. There are parts of the tutorial and tips that are not voiced and I found that this was a little disappointing as the rest of the game is voiced appropriately.

I found really hard to use mouse as ascending and descending the wheel ended up with me flipping over the majority of the time without reason. I ultimately decided to play without it. I didnâ€™t test the gamepad controls. I also found that it is hard not to have a mini map or an equal amount of signs on the off-road maps. This made me fall off the track, driving in nonsensical directions and unable to guess which way I was supposed to go,game doesnâ€™t even tell you that you are going in to a wrong direction in off-road maps,so only way to check it is to look at your position.

PROS: Variety of vehicles â€“ (It was great having an option to switch between vehicle types (bikes, ATVs, UTVs, sports trucks and buggies)

Variety of maps â€“ (Having an option to switch between maps was great as too was the addition of the free ride system.)

Variety of tricks â€“ (Players have the freedom to pull out almost any trick imaginable.)

Customization (Being able to customize every part of your vehicle as well as every visual component including the driver was a sweet touch.)

Multiplayer â€“ (The fact that the multiplayer component of the game is alive is awesome.)

Effects â€“ (The graphics are decent but they are no longer impressive aside from the water and physics effects.)

Gamepad support â€“ (The game provides gamepad support which I imagine would make it easier for the player to pull off tricks and maneuvers)
CONS:Poor HUD, lack of minimap â€“ (Not having a minimap or an adequate amount of signs in the off-road challenge was the most disappointing aspect of the game.)

Mouse controls â€“ (The mouse control were poor to the point that I had to give up on them.)

reviewText:
Reflex is still king, 2016.
GAMEPLAY:

There is plenty of content to take on in Reflex. For example, there's a handful of national and supercross tracks to race on. In addition, there are also a ton of different game modes for you to have fun with such as FMX competitions, racing off-road trucks, UTV's, or buggies etc. Most importantly (for me) is that the base game has a decent amount of customization options from gear, to bike parts, and graphic kits. ALTHOUGH, if you get sick of the same old skins (as well as tracks), then go visit http://reflex-central.com/ for some mods.

Moving on, I've found it quite hard to always have a perfect lap considering that the track develops lines (or ruts) the more you ride on it. In other words, every lap feels like a different approach is needed unless you can follow through with your exact line perfectly.

CONTROLS:

While using a controller to play the game, you use the left analog stick to steer your bike and the right analog stick to control your rider. So if you were to ride a berm to the left, you would basically move both sticks to the left to make your rider lean into the berm. Furthermore, if you were to speed over some whoops, you would move the right stick only backwards so that your rider leans a bit back to absord the rough part of the track.

ONLINE:

I still find a ton of racers online in 2016. Although, online gameplay is where the cons are for me. For example, racing with other races can be challenging (or annoying) considering how it appears that your opponents are bouncing around all over the track. Furthermore, there is this thing known as the whip glitch that allows you to easily clear jumps. A lot of online racers abuse this, whip glitch" making them ultimately faster than you unless you can do it too. If you want to have a fair race

Lots of pointless stuff too. If you want to complete moto-career 100% you need to race in Sports Trucks, Buggys, and UTV's which are no where near as much fun as the ATV's and MX (at least when it comes to video games), but it's totally optional stuff.

Now before you say this review isnt helpful just because your a fan boy of the game really think about my reasoning and why I might not recommend this game.

Gameplay: Overall the gameplay is good. The bikes feel smooth the movement feels natural and on a good track feels really flowy. The only thing I dont like about this games riding is the way the bikes feel. The bikes feel almost like they dont have any weight. A good comparison is probably Skyrim's melee fighting.

My GF got me this game, and we played it together expecting a PC quality game, what we got has the feel of a last minute port from xbox 360.
The graphics are pretty good, but have few actual settings, and your tire tracks shine and sparkle, whether it's in mud, dirt, or snow. Snow and mud make sense, but dirt does not sparkle nor shine, so that is poorly done.
The dynamic terrain is mostly astetic, you need to race several laps to where the dirt piles into mounds before it will actually effect your driving, whether it's in a vehicle or the (what should be) much more sensitive to terrain motocross bike.
The only controller supported is the Xbox 360 one, which is sad since legacy controller support like most PC games use will let you map ANY controller, if you use ANY other controller, have xpadder on hand, and be ready for worse sensitivity than you should ever have with an analog stick.
Another thing on sensitivity, there isn't any settings for it on keyboard, or even if you use the supported controller, so expect to do hard turns on smooth corners a lot.
Tilting should have you Lean and break/gas/steer, the game is supposed to be specifically for the combination of leaning, and throttle/break/steering, but leaning wont effect forward and back tilting in the air, not even on MX, it's only the gas and break, it's unrealistic when you can lean backwards but you tilt forwards because you're breaking, and invalidates the game's primary selling point.
Air time is a little bit much and vaguley borderline realistic, it doesn't really bother gameplay since most people enjoy the extra air time, nor does it stand out as arcade-esk airtime.

All in all, if you still use the dated 360 controller for gaming on PC (Or you like keyboards for racing games), you dont mind the graphics of a last minute console port, and you dont really care about the whole reflex" part of the game (since it's vaguley there)

MX vs ATV: Reflex is an impressive offroad racing game which, contrary to its title, allows you to drive not only two classes of MX bikes and ATVs but also several types of offroad cars, from buggies to 4x4 trucks.

Developed by the team behind the classic Motocross Madness series, MX vs ATV offers a variety of racing modes across closed stadium and outdoor tracks as well as several open-world maps in different climate zones, from mudland to snowy mountains. What makes MX vs ATV particularly fun (and authentic) is the combination of precise controls (including weight shifting) and ground deformation. Only a few games have so far featured the latter (Sega Rally Revo did it best). Every vehicle leaves a track in the ground, changing the surface and making subsequent laps more difficult. This makes for an additional challenge, especially in longer races.

Graphics are decent, but it's obvious that the game was made with consoles in mind. The level of texture detail and draw distance are limited, as are filtering and anti-aliasing features.

This is a very fun and content-rich offroad racing game that appeals in particular to fans of the old Motocross Madness series.

At first glance this game is a pretty good continuance of the MX vs ATV series. Mx vs Atv Reflex looks like a game that any extreme sports fan, weekend warrior or family could enjoy. With its fast paced action, high flying daredevil stunts and free roaming what's not to enjoy. So put your helmets on and lets go for a ride!

The visuals are pretty good considering it was produced in 2011.The vehicles are pretty on par with their real life counter parts. The motos look like motos the atvs like atvs. The only true visual on a vehicle that gets me is the lack of an axle underneath the sport trucks during full compression. Its like the just have wheels. The motion blur is a nice touch and the scenery is ok.  The landscapes are massive with tons of room to play around. The land deformation is awesome with every pass through the tracks conditions change.The water however is terrible. The physics for some reason or another make it react if its a giant bowl of jelly. When racing through it it tends to engulf your character when riding something without doors. The shrubs also tend to be an issue. They seem to just get in the field of view at the right moment. I find myself running into the trees directly behind these shrubs more than enough. The HUD could have also used some attention. The lack of a circuit map, especially on the Omniraces, leaves you with trying to make the right turns at the right times.

The amount of vehicles in the game is vast. MX, ATV, Short Course trucks, Buggies and even Rhinos. You can customize them to a certain degree with physical mods such as colors, wraps, handlebars etc and performance wise with exhaust, suspension, and tires. This here is where I have a problem. Within the physical mods and performance mods you have Brand name manufacturers that anyone in the moto scene would know FMF, Yoshimura, Maxxis, but the actual vehicles themselves lack brands. There is no definitve Honda or Yamaha. There is KTM, but how come they couldn't seem to get the rest. Its not a deal breaker just annoying. When it comes to your rider though the options almost seem endless. Goggles, helmets, jerseys, boots. with multiple designs for each brand.These options ad a nice touch, but I still can't get passed my rider decked out in Troy Lee and he's riding a Dakumoto 450.

The career mode is a simple linear progression. Complete these races, unlock this, repeat. Sure there's a reason behind it. You have to complete certain series to unlock certain vehicle types to complete another series. It's just to flat and linear to actually enjoy. If they would have thrown in a career mode with the goal ofgetting sponsored and making your way through the ranks of the series I would have found that more compelling and worth continuing. Instead I find myself rinsing and repeating hoping that the A.I. will get better the more I progress. Boy was I wrong.

The A.I. in Mx vs Atv is either borderline â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ or crazy. (Depending on what they choose.) It is a reacurring issue for me to continually win races 25+ seconds ahead of my nearest competitor. Thought it was too easy and bumped the difficulty up to the highest and it's absolutely the same. Every now and then you'll find someone able to hang in with you for a little bit, but once they mess up they never catch back up. The A.I. is the most ridiculous during Omniraces which pit every vehicle type against each other. If your not in a truck or buggy be prepared to be ran over time and time again leading to frustration and the enevitable rage quit. But your not even safe then. They will run into you after you've rolled and top side down with no regard to their own position. I don't know who was in charge of A.I.,, but I sure would love to know where he learned about racing.

The games mechanics are alright, but a drastic change to the series. Your control not only throttle and brake, but also the lean left and right. This inturn is supposed to make it more challenging to race, but as previously stated the A.I. is just too stupid to captialize. All you really need to worry about is preloading for jumps and correcting the landings when told to. The trick library is pretty cool. Simplistic tricks from nic nacs to Kisses of Death are all included. However I don't really like the way to perform tricks. Up Down Right will perform one, but it's too easy to mess up and accidentally do a more time consuming complicated trick. I would have prefered if simpler tricks were to way combinations and complex tricks 3 or 4.

If want to get the most fun out of this game you'll find it in the free rides. Being able to ride around aimlesslly pulling off backflips and supermans is nice. Just dont get to a spot with no easy way down. For some reason or another when on a hard to reach peak if you eat it going down or falling off it just endlesslly respawns you were you began your descend. I advise you stick to the low grounds if you don't want to spend 10 minutes hoping you land a 100 foot drop.

All in all Mx vs ATV Reflex isn't a bad game. Yes the career is bland and the lack of real bikes and quads in a Motocross game is perplexing not to mention the pyschopathic A.I. and sometimes confusing races this game is worth a play. Atleast for a little bit... 7/10

God, this was awful. Just awful.

My main complaint is the new dual stick mechanic introduced. While it's kind of a cool idea on paper, it's horrible in practice. Any jump of any size now naturally pulls back, and if you don't compensate, you will crash. You can't really just ride anymore. You constantly have to focus on what you're doing with the right stick (or mouse). Since tricks are also tied to the same stick (mouse), any time you try to pull off a trick, your movements will naturally throw you off balance, and making it incredibly likely that you'll crash, since the mechanic loses all of it power to change your movement the second you leave the ground, making it hard to compensate for throwing yourself off.

There are some things that I like some what. The physics were pretty good, and I was fairly impressed with the trails you make (whether with your bike, or your lifeless body after you crash) in the dirt as you ride around.

I was serverely disappointed with this game though; I was hoping to go back to my old memories of the old MX vs. ATV on my PS2. If the Reflex Control mechanic could be turned off, I would love this. However, since I got this game, along with a few other games and extras from Humble Bundle for the total price of $2.50, I can complain too much. I just have to sulk whenever I pass it in my library.
